description: Master Reactive Extensions for JavaScript (RxJS) to handle asynchronous data streams in Angular.

slides.title: What is RxJS?
slides.content:
# Reactive Extensions âš¡

RxJS is a library for reactive programming using **Observables**.

Think of an Observable as an array that arrives over time.

Angular relies heavily on RxJS for HTTP, Forms, and Routing.

slides.title: Observable vs Promise
slides.content:
# The Difference ðŸ¥Š

**Promise:**
- Handles a single event.
- Runs immediately (Eager).
- Cannot be cancelled.

**Observable:**
- Handles a stream of events (0 to many).
- Runs only when subscribed (Lazy).
- Can be cancelled (Unsubscribe).

slides.title: Subscription Management
Async Pipe
slides.content:
# The Async Pipe ðŸš¿ The BEST way to handle observables. It subscribes automatically when the component loads and unsubscribes when it is destroyed. ```html
{{ item.name }}
``` (Convention: append `$` to observable variables).

slides.title: Operators
slides.content:
# Operators ðŸ”§

Functions that transform data in the stream.

Use `.pipe()` to chain them.

```typescript
import { map, filter } from 'rxjs/operators';

myObs$.pipe(
  filter(x => x > 10),
  map(x => x * 2)
).subscribe(...)
```

slides.title: Common Operators
slides.content:
# Must Know Operators ðŸ§°

- `map`: Transform values.
- `tap`: Side effects (log data) without changing it.
- `filter`: Filter values.
- `switchMap`: Switch to a new observable (cancel previous). Great for Type-ahead search.

slides.title: Subjects
slides.content:
# Subjects ðŸ“¢

A Subject is both an Observable (you can subscribe) and an Observer (you can emit data).

```typescript
const subject = new Subject<number>();

subject.subscribe(v => console.log(v));
subject.next(1); // Emits 1
```

slides.title: BehaviorSubject
slides.content:
# BehaviorSubject ðŸ§ 

A Subject that requires an initial value and always emits the current value to new subscribers.

Perfect for holding state (like "Current User").

```typescript
const user$ = new BehaviorSubject('Guest');
```

slides.title: ForkJoin
slides.content:
# Combining Streams ðŸ¤

`forkJoin` is like `Promise.all`.

Wait for multiple observables to complete, then emit the final values as an array.

```typescript
forkJoin([
  http.get('/users'),
  http.get('/books')
]).subscribe(([users, books]) => ...)
```

# Recap: RxJS ðŸŽ“

Stream Processing.

- **Observable:** Stream of events.
- **Subscribe:** Start listening.
- **Operators:** Map, Filter, SwitchMap.
- **Async Pipe:** Handle subs automatically.
- **Subjects:** Multicast data.
